title: Are Samurai swords the best swords in the world? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. They’re not the best swords in the world. However, unlike some seem to think, they’re good swords, among many others. There’s a recent trend of bashing on the katana too much. You’ll hear words like “pig iron” thrown around a lot innacurately. Pig Iron is a type of steel with an carbon content of between 3.8% and 4.7% ; the steel used traditionally in a Katana has an carbon content of between 0.5% and 1.2% ; much lower than that of pig iron. They are bashed for not cutting into armor, though no sword can cut into well-made metallic armor, or for being too fragile, not durable enough. So, I’ll try to dispell a few myths. Katana are interesting weapons. Their main characteristics are these : 1 - Differential Hardening  The wave pattern is the Hamon. They are hardened to have a harder edge (ha) and a softer spine (mune). That actually improves the durability of the sword, allowing it to bend rather than break. You just have to bend it back, though it will not be as solid as before. It also allows the edge to be very hard - therefore be able to hold an amazing edge without having a fragile sword. * Compared to modern European swords, generally modern European swords are spring tempered. Spring-tempering is homogenous across the blade. Those swords just “spring back” like a spring and are very durable, more so than a traditionnaly-made Katana. That durability comes at the price of a minor hardness sacrifice, because the sword is homogenous. Too hard means holding an excellent edge, but having a brittle sword, prone to breakage. 2 - Thickness and rigidity :  A Katana has a thick body, making it seem rather bulky by European standards. That thickness makes it forgiving in the case of a cut with improper edge alignement, because the katana won’t spring around but remain steady throughout the cut. It allows less skilled people to perform cuts properly, and tends to improve the quality of the resulting cut. However, a major mistake means bending your Katana. * In comparison, European swords are thinner, that with a spring-treatment means it is less forgiving of mistakes in edge-alignement and therefore you will need more skill to cut as successfully. 3 - Length :  For this part, I’ll compare it to a longsword for merely informative purposes. A Katana tends to be shorter than most two handed swords. Indeed, the total lenght of a Katana can vary between 90cm and 112cm, sometimes up to 120cm. A Longsword is usually between 110 and 130cm. Does that mean a major difference in reach ? It’s a bit more complicated. You have to understand a concept ; that of the sweetspot. It is the part of the sword that cuts the most effectively. In Japanese, it is called the “Monouchi”. The sweet spot of the Katana is a few centimeters behind the Kissaki (tip-part). On the other hand, many longswords taper a lot toward the tip, bringing their sweet spot backward, and making the effective cutting range shorter than the actual lenght of the sword. As such, for cuts, the difference is nonexistent to minor. However for thrusts, the range is indeed longer on a longer blade.

No. I don’t even need to know what you want to use it for. The answer is still no. Now, the katana isn’t a bad [1]sword. Not at all. It’s a perfectly good, albeit short, two handed sword. But there are many other swords that do the job just as well. It also depends on what you want the sword to do, and what you like in swords. Personally I’m not very interested in katanas because they lack features [2]that I like. Even if a katana were made dimensionally correct for me, 100cm of blade and 33cm of hilt, they have underdeveloped guards (compared with later European longswords) and while they can hold a sharper edge longer, they’re also more brittle. I prefer spring-tempered European monosteel. Interestingly, for a secondary defense sword, a wakazashi might work pretty well for me. My usual preference, messers, have a nagel (protrusion on the side of the guard) that protects the hands and allows for a few particular actions that rely on the nagle being there.  Wakazasi have guards have similar side protection which may work much like a messer, and longer wakazashi are similar in length to shorter messers.  Look, the bottom line is that the “best sword in the world” not only doesn’t exist, it cannot exist. There is no one magical sword that is perfectly suitable for all tasks to which a sword be applied. Swords are optimized for different tasks in different contexts, and on top of that people have different preferences.  Original question-Are Samurai swords the best swords in the world? Footnotes[1] Murphy Barrett's answer to Why do some people think katanas are poor weapons?[2] Murphy Barrett's answer to How would you improve the katana?

Yes For the past decades, the Katana has been widely known around the world, among the melee weapon lovers, as “the best sword”.Through movies and video games, we are all victims of cultural marketing. Samurai, Ninja, game or movie protagonists often seen with a Katana, and excels in combat that beats any other weapons. Where at the same time, other more superior and practical weapons were bias-ed and only used by either the villains, the supporting characters, who would either get killed or lose to the sword. In the martial arts world, Japanese sword related school had gain a good number of new students due to its popularity: Kendo / Kenjutsu / etc. It is quite common to see new students coming in with requests to learn specifically just the sword, because they are “the best”. When you can implant (or brain wash) people with such perception, no matter how reasonable we try to persuade, it would not change their mind so easily.

Which one do you mean by ‘Samurai' swords? Are you talking about the most mainstream sword, katana? Or are you talking about its taller cousin, nodachi? Or its shorter brother, wakizashi? Or maybe the even less popular one, naginata, which is basically a sword attached to a long staff and then used like a spear? (Some would argue that it's completely a spear, but many also shares my opinion) Since you don't provide some detail, I'd assume what you're talking about is the katana. Common people, especially weaboos, tend to think that samurais went to the battle using only their katanas, swinging them around like some sort of ancient Japanese Jedis who can't be touched by nothing, and their swords are made of magic steel forged by demi gods in sacred forge and then imbued with Shinto mantras. Let me tell you, friend, you're wrong. Katana, compared to most of European swords , are rather fragile. To use one properly, you need more training than you would with a, say, longsword. Like Murphy said it's a good sword, it serves a purpose, but it's definitely not the best. It cuts great, but its edge is quite brittle and easy to chip. The term ‘best' is relative; the best sword exists, but not the way you think. When a sword suits you perfectly and you can use it as easy as swinging your own arm, then that's the best sword for you. But there's no sword that is the best in the way it simply exceeds any other kind. All and all, it comes back to the one who holds it, because like an old general once says… “Sure it matters who's got the biggest stick, but it matters a helluva lot more who swinging it”

The design of swords and other hand weapons changed over time according to the context in which they were being used, the materials available, and the armor worn by combatants. When armor (including shields) changed, so did the weapons made to go against it, which led to more changes in armor, then changes in the weapons, on and on and on. Japanese weapons at any given point in time were adapted to what opponents were likely to wear, the type of steel available, and the way that warfare was conducted. Katanas (and other Japanese swords) worked well in the time, place, and culture in which they were used. They wouldn’t necessarily be the best choice in other contexts. Some hand weapons work best for slicing. Some are great for chopping. Some excel at stabbing. Some are primarily impact weapons. Many excel at one or two of those things, with less utility for other types of damage. Katanas are optimized for slashing and slicing attacks. They can stab and chop, too, but not as well as weapons that are optimized for those actions. They aren’t great at impact attacks. Given that, they work well in close combat situations with unarmored or lightly armored opponents, but wouldn’t be a good choice against heavy European style metal armor, where weapons optimized for impact and piercing/stabbing attacks work best (ex. warhammers).

Every sword has to be considered in the time and place it was made, and the purpose it was made for. No one sword is best for all purposes. The traditional katana has a very sharp blade, with a softer structural core, and a slight curve. This helps it slice through soft material, and was useful in a time when good quality metal was scarce and most armor was made from silk or other soft material. A katana is a very good sword for slicing. However, you would not want to hit it against thick metal armor, or another sword, as that would be likely to crack the slicing edge and possibly even bend the softer structural core. Katanas were not for fighting armored targets. For fighting someone in heavy armor, you’d be better off with something like a claymore, which isn’t as sharp but is very heavy and tough, or maybe even a fencing sword with isn’t good for slicing but has reach and is nimble and good for aiming at joints and eye-holes.

Q: Are Samurai swords the best swords in the world? A: No. It’s a cool and beautiful type of sword, that fit its eras, location and arms technology perfectly. It’s outstanding as a cutting blade, and has an extraordinarily good grip. But the blade is very stiff blade with a very brittle edge. Against soft targets, it’s great; against hard metal armour, it’s not that great. If you use it as a cavalry saber or backup weapon against conscripted peasants or other samurai, it’s good. Use it in duels against other samurai, and again, it’s great. Use one in a movie, and I’ll drool. Put one on my wall, please, and I will be happy as a clam! But put it in just about any other context, and it is the wrong weapon at the wrong place.

hello cameron Thanks for the A2A its is kind of what is the best battle riffle of WWII question. a sword (or any weapon) is the per-equation of what you can produce and what you are going to use it for. best at what? what period ? i mean shape and the construction changed across time . however a long handle and thick blade is a recurring theme. The long handle is the price for maneuverability for the thickness and the wedge shape of the blade   Are tashi/katana better than Chinese or European folded differential hardening steel sword? No not really. A Replica of the Sutton Hoo Sword - Ganoksin Jewelry Making Community. Homogeneous steel, crucible or wootz/bulat/damascus are/were more adapted to produce lighter sword yes a tashi katana cuts well, Though single handed and provided you use shoulder cut a tulwar/pulwar, a pelash or even a euro military light cavalry saber will cut just as well. or late medieval euro long sword will have more reach and will be better at tip cutting than a tashi katana. but Tashi/katan are not designed with level of protection of a late medieval European Armour in mind So for the ore quality that Japaneses had to work with and the usage that had for it, yes it is the best. If you ask me if i had to pick a sword to fight another swordsman. I will go for a type XVIIIe or a long bladed pointy type XX. Phil

Well, the thing is; there is no “best sword in the world” Is the katana/odachi/any sword used by the samurai good swords? Hell yes, they were good, but good at what they are designed for: cutting. Japanese blades tend to suffer some bit when trying to stab, since their fronts are generally not as optimized for stabbing (though this does not mean that they could not stab! They very well could, only not as good as some of the european longswords and especially the rapier). The problem with the question here is that regarding the katana, there are two common types of people; those that absolutely adore and fanboy it, and those who absolutely bash it to bits. The katana is definitely a sword that you can try to have if you are a HEMA(well, more like just any swordfighting) enthusiast as me, they are excellent swords mind you, but when practicing martial arts, please do keep in mind their restrictions.

The katana was once idolized in western culture, popularized in movies such as Highlander, Blade, and Kill Bill. This adulation spawned a counter-movement that criticizes the katana for failing to live up to its mythical status. It’s not unlike the way Kung Fu is regarded in western culture. Once upon a time, coincidentally enough around the same time as the katana craze, Kung Fu was thought to be able to grant one superhuman abilities. Nowadays, Kung Fu is criticized for not being a “real” fighting art. It’s basically the same dynamic. The truth is, legends of invincible katanas are just that: legends. The Japanese certainly do not believe every single katana is amazing. They simply have legends about amazing, sometimes even magical, swords. Much like European culture has legends about Excalibur and Durendal, Japanese culture has legends about Masamune and Muramasa. Somehow, western audiences interpreted the mythical qualities attributed to those legendary katanas as being possessed by *any* katana. Imagine if the Japanese thought every European straight sword was indestructible and capable of cutting through giant boulders with a single strike, and you’d understand the absurdity of the western views on the Japanese katana.

Yes and no. If you're a samurai, yes. If you're trained some other way, no. “Which sword is better?” is analogous to asking the army what their best gun is. To a sniper, a preferred type of long arm. To an infantryman, a preferred type of assault rifle. Every weapon has a purpose, a function, and is good at it (or they wouldn't remain in wide use).

Currently, most popular and beautiful and best sword in the world is the Samurai sword. There’s no doubt about it. Though the biggest worry for almost everyone is that a real samurai sword can cost up to a few thousand bucks to buy. In case you cannot spare this much money then there’s still a way left for you to get cheap Samurai swords.
No. They’re great for what they had been created for, and considering the crappy metal they’re made, they are very well forged. But they’re not Ulfberht swords - Wikipedia made of damascus steel.
